physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. Aldington's address is typed in the heading on the top left of the front page: Richard Aldington, Esq. Malthouse Cottage Padworth Reading, Berks England. On the second page, “Mr. Aldington - 2” is typed on the right side of the heading. On both pages, there are some tears on the right side of the paper.

div.p: Here are the half-yearly royalties on those poor little Imagist Anthologies. Every year I think it will be the last, and every year there are a few cents coming from them. The account is as follows:

I read your article on James Joyce, the other day, in the “Literary Review” of the New York “Evening Post,” but I am willing to wager a good deal that you are wrong in your contentions, at least as far as this country is concerned. He is certainly having no effect over here. It is very interesting to me to watch the development of our two countries. For good or bad, they are growing farther apart all the time. The things that have influence in one country do not have influence in the other, and so on. One would have expected a wide discussion of Joyce. It has not come. Lawrence, on the other hand, is having quite an influence over here now, doing, in fact, very well indeed.

I had to put off going to England this year because the Keats book, which I am writing, could not be done in time. I doubt now whether it will be out before the Autumn of 1923. I have found considerable new material over here, and the hunting up of sources is a slow, fatiguing task. I do not suppose I should ever have started on it if I had not got interested in writing the centenary address which I gave at Yale last year.

This is not much of a letter and does not contain much news, but
I am going off on a lecture trip on Monday, and there are so many things to be done that I am in despair; particularly I have to finish a lecture on Chinese poetry to be delivered at Bryn Mawr next week. This last is rapidly turning my hair grey.

I do not know whether you have seen my friend Mrs. Ayscough's and my Chinese translations. I did not send you the book because I thought you were rather tired of my things. I will if you would like to look at it, but I hate to bother people. It will shortly be published by Constable's in England.

Now I must stop. Forgive this short letter, but I am absolutely drowned in things which must be done before I leave. I wish you would write sometimes. We seenseem to know nothing of each other's doings now. Again I hope to get over next Summer, but it depends so much on the work.

postscript.label: P.S.
postscript.p: I do not know Flint's address, so I am sending you his draft as I did before.
